R., artwork sales Maria Carolina B. R., handiwork sales Veronica Liliana G. B., jewelry sales Luz Marina B. R., handicraft sales Jorgelina M. P., food sales Analia Roxana B., grocery sales Nery R. B., bread sales Gladys Martina P. de Zárate, food sales Rosa Maria P. C., clothing sales Marciana B. de Ramos, bread sales Maria Valeria U. de Campos, Manufacture and sales of cleaning products.

Each of these women will receive a small part of the loan to invest in merchandise, basic materials and/or materials necessary for her respective business. For those who are in the manufacture and sales of food, it's to buy fruit, vegetables, sugar, eggs, oil, meat and spices, as well as, soda, juices, dairy and mineral water. For those who make and sell crafts and handicrafts, it will be invested in palm leaves and mud. For those who manufacture and sell cleaning products and detergent, it will be invested in chemicals. And for those who sell clothing, it will be to buy clothing for men and women, shoes, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, meat, dairy, soda, handicrafts, detergent, etc.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita S. tiene tres hijos, ella vive en Tecpán Guatemala Chimaltenango, su negocio es una fabrica de ropa para bebe.  Desde muy pequeña Margarita se dedicó a los negocios, su primer negocio fue vender plantas medicinales, así como también atender los nacimientos de niños.
También inicio un negocio de crianza de pollos, pero por no tener experiencia, no le fue muy bien y se le murieron todos sus pollos.
Siguió luchando y con la ayuda de su esposo logró comprar 3 vacas, las que pronto tendrán sus crías, por eso esta muy contenta.  También cuenta que no tenia posibilidades de darles educación a sus hijos, y por eso desde hace cuatro años se dedicaron junto con su esposo a trabajar para fabricas de suéteres, y de esa forma fueron aprendiendo y adquiriendo  experiencia, por lo que nació la idea de comprar su propia maquina de tejidos para elaborar trajes de bebe.  Actualmente es uno de sus hijos el quien le ayuda a administrar su negocio, y ahora ya puede estudiar él y también su hijo mas pequeño va a la escuela.  Su sueño es poder construir su casa y que sus hijos sean estudien y lleguen a ser profesionales, y personas de bien.
texts.en:
Margarita S. is a woman who has 3 children and lives in Tecpán Guatemala Chimaltenango. She has a baby apparel factory. Ever since she was young, Margarita has been in retail. Her first business was herbal remedy sales. She also assisted in delivering babies. She started a chicken farm as well, but because she had no experience in that line of work, things did not go well and all her chickens died.

She kept working hard, and with the help of her husband, was able to purchase 3 cows, which will soon have their own young. This is why she is very happy. She also notes that she did not have an opportunity to provide her children with an education, which is why they, along with their dad, went to work at a sweater factory four years ago. As a consequence, they started learning skills and obtaining experience, which is how the idea to purchase a knitting machine to make baby outfits was born. One of her children currently helps her manage the business, and he can now study. Her youngest son now attends school as well. She dreams of being able to build her own house and of seeing her children get an education so that they can be upright professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies to make sweaters and baby apparel

loans.name: Mirna Haydee

texts.es:
Mirna es casada y tiene 3 hijos, ya solo una esta estudiando y vive con su padre.  Ella tiene aproximadamente 2 años y seis meses de estar presa en la cárcel de mujeres Santa Teresa.  Durante ese periodo y mientras espera salir en libertad, ella se ha dedicado a la fabricación y venta de candelas y veladoras de cera, y ha participado en todos los procesos de capacitación y formación empresarial que FAPE ha promovido y también otras organizaciones que apoyan a las internas en la cárcel.

Desde hace mas de un año, ha encontrado la posibilidad de hacer negocios en la cárcel, su suegra tiene una panadería, y le provee de pan y pasteles, los cuales ella vende, y le ha ido muy bien en este negocio, por lo cual espera con el préstamo que obtenga, pueda invertir y aprovechar mucho la época navideña.

Mirna sueña con salir en libertad, y ella poner su propia panadería, ya que también ha adquirido conocimiento del proceso de hacer y vender pan.  Este préstamo lo utilizará para invertido en la materia prima de hacer pan por medio de su suegra, y ella venderlo dentro de la cárcel.

Mirna es una mujer admirable, que a pesar de las circunstancias de estar privada de libertad esta saliendo adelante y siendo ejemplo para muchas otras mujeres.  Ella es el modelo de mujeres que este proyecto de apoyo a mujeres presas en la cárcel FAPE quiere apoyar, ella cuenta con una visión clara de lo que hará cuando salga de la cárcel.
texts.en:
Mirna is married and has 3 children, one of whom is still in school and lives with her father. She has been incarcerated at the Santa Teresa Women’s Prison for approximately 2 years and 6 months. During this period, while waiting to be released, she has been making and selling wax candles. She has also participated in training sessions and received business training from FAPE and other organizations that give support to female inmates. For over a year, she has been given the possibility to have a business in jail. Her mother-in-law owns a bakery and provides her with bread and cake, which she then sells. Her business has been lucrative, which is why she hopes to invest the loan and take advantage of the Christmas season. Mirna dreams of being released from prison so that she can set up her own bakery because she has also learned how to bake and sell bread. She will invest this loan in purchasing the ingredients that her mother-in-law needs to make bread so that she can sell it in jail. Mirna is an admirable woman who, despite the fact that she does not have freedom, is moving forward and setting an example for many other women. She is the type of person that the FAPE female inmate program wants to support. She has a clear vision of what she will do when she is released from jail.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make bread

loans.name: Marta Mayra

texts.es: Doña Marta, habita en el barrio de Sabana Grande, tiene 50 años de edad, es soltera, y no tiene hijos, su trabajo en la elaboración de ricas cosa de hornos, rosquillas, desde hace treinta y cinco años  pues es heredad de sus abuelos, ya que su fuente de trabajo ha sido los horneados desde muy niña, pues no ha sido fácil por que es un trabajo donde se agita mucho a demás que hay que darle el punto a la rosquillas. Con esta solicitud es la segunda la cual va invertir en materia prima en la compra de maíz, queso, dulce, azúcar, manteca y otros productos que ocupa para hacer las rosquillas, más que todo desea aumentar las ventas para lograr mejores ingresos, A largo plazo es poder mejorar la infraestructura del horno para seguir con su trabajo.
texts.en:
Marta lives in the neighbourhood of Sabana Grande; she is 50 years old, single, and has no children. She has had a business baking sweets, donuts, for the past 35 years, an inheritance from her grandparents. Her work has revolved around baking since she was a very young girl even though it is not easy work as it takes a lot of stirring to shape the donuts. With this, her second loan request, she will buy raw materials such as corn, cheese, sweets, sugar, butter, and other products which she needs. Above all, she wants to increase her sales to increase revenues. Her long-term goal is to rebuild her oven to continue her work.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn, cheese, and butter in bulk

loans.name: Susana Hilaria

texts.es: Doña Susana tiene 62 años de edad, habita en Villa Venezuela del parque  ocho andenes al sur, en la capital de Managua, con ocho hijos cuatro mujeres y cuatro varones, cuatro están casados y son independiente,  los otros trabajan y a poyan a su mama, la Sra. Susana tiene un salón de belleza desde hace diecisiete años que inicio con esfuerzos propios el cual ha sido el sustento para la familia, con esta solicitud es la séptima en Afodenic, ha sido de gran beneficios ya que ha invertido en la compra de inventario para el salón, con esta préstamo es comprar productos variados para trabajar como cremas de alisar, tintes , tratamientos para el cutis y otros ya que es una temporada en donde la gente obtiene un poco mas de dinero y opta por cambiar el look de su cabello para estar con una imagen diferente, a largo plazo es comprar su propio terreno para mejorar el local de su salón, y apoyar  a sus hijos en lo que pueda.
texts.en:
Susana is 62 years old, lives in Villa Venezuela del parque ocho andenes al sur, in the capital Managua. She has 8 children: 4 girls and 4 boys. Four of her children are married and live on their own; her other children work and help their mother. Susana has owned a beauty salon for the past 17 years, which she started with her own efforts and which has allowed her to raise her family. This is her seventh loan with Afodenic; previous loans have been of great benefit as she has invested them in buying inventory for her salon. With this loan, she will buy a variety of products for her work, such as smoothing creams, hair dye, skin treatments and others as this is the season when people spend a little more and choose to change the look of their hair and change their image. Her long-term goal is to buy her own land in order to improve the location of her salon, and help her children as much as she can.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products such as hair dye, and hair treatment products.

loans.name: Segunda Ines

texts.es:
La señora Segunda Inés tiene 64 años D. edad, pertenece al Grupo Solidario Manuel Seoane y vive en la calle Manuel Carrera Mz 14 lote 9  del distrito D. La Esperanza, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta segundo grado D. primaria, su madre murió, la dejó muy niña y tuvo que trabajar para poder ayudar con la economía del hogar. Se casó a los 15 años y tiene 6 hijos, todos casados y un nieto que depenD. D. ella, aún es estudiante.
Su negocio consiste en la venta D. bebidas y comida, actividad que realiza en Puerto Morín.
Con este crédito D. S/. 300, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará gaseosa.
Segunda sueña con tener un gran restaurant.
texts.en:
Segunda Ines, 64, belongs to the Manuel Seoane support group. She lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She left school in the second graD. when her mother died. Still a young girl, she had to work to help her family. She married at 15 and has 6 children, all married, and one grandson who depends on her and is still in school. She operates a business selling drinks and food at Puerto Morin. With this loan of S/.300 [300 Peruvian soles], to be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy soft drinks. Segunda would like to have a large restaurant someday.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soft drinks for resale.

loans.name: Luz De Lourdes

texts.es: Doña Luz tiene 36 años de edad, habita en un barrio que se llama 14 de Febrero, con tres hijos de 7, 15,17 años de edad, que están estudiando, su esposo se desempeña como contador general en una empresa privada, la Sra. Luz tiene una pulpería y vende ropa, zapatos y cosméticos desde hace cinco años, que comenzó con préstamo que hizo en otras financieras, con esta solicitud es la quinta en Afodenic pues una institución con bajos intereses y le ha sido de grandes beneficios para su capital de trabajo, con este préstamo desea invertir en la compra de granos básicos, cosméticos, para cumplir con los pedidos de sus clientes y así poder tener mas ingresos con las ventas. A largo plazo es invertir más, ayudar a sus hijos a que progresen con los estudios.
texts.en:
Luz is 36 years old, lives in a neighbourhood called 14 de Febrero, has three children aged 7, 15, and 17 years who are students. Her husband works as a general accountant in a private company. Luz owns a store and has sold clothes, shoes, and cosmetics for the past 5 years. She started her business with a loan which she financed elsewhere. This is her fifth loan with Afodenic, an institution with low interest rates and which has helped her greatly to provide her with working capital. She plans to invest this loan in the purchase of basic staples, cosmetics, in order to fulfill the demand from her clients and therefore make more revenue from her sales. Her long-term goal is to invest more, helping her children as they continue their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic staples and cosmetics.

loans.name: Betty Gloria

texts.es:
La señora Betty Gloria tiene 53 años de edad, pertenece al Grupo Solidario Manuel Seoane y vive en Mz 2  lote 2 de Winchanzao,  distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta el segundo año de secundaria y no lo concluyó porque se casó a los 16 años. Actualmente tiene 8 hijos, de los cuales fallecieron 2 niñas gemelas. Todos sus hijos viven independientemente.
Su negocio consiste en la venta ambulante de útiles de limpieza. Con su primer crédito de S/. 200 que canceló en 4 meses invirtió en la compra de desinfectantes y escobas.
Con este crédito de S/. 500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en mercadería.
Betty sueña con ser mayorista de productos de limpieza.
texts.en:
Betty Gloria is fifty-three years old, belongs to Manuel Seoane Support Group and lives in Mz 2 lot 2 of Winchanzao, district of La Esperanza, in the province of Trujillo, apartment La Libertad, Peru. She studied until her sophomore year of high school and did not finish because she got married at the age of sixteen. Now she has had eight children, two of which were twin girls who passed away. All her children live independently. Her business is in the traveling sale of cleaning products. With her first loan of S/. 200, which she repaid in four months, she invested in purchasing disinfectants and brooms. With this loan of S/. 500, which will be repaid in four installments, she will invest in merchandise. Betty dreams of being a wholesaler of cleaning products.

Translated from Spanish by Hannah Lily, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing merchandise

loans.name: Edith Gisela

texts.es:
La señora Edith Gisela tiene 19 años, es la tesorera del Grupo Solidario  Manuel Seoane y vive en la calle Manuel Carera Mz 20 lote 2 del distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta primero de secundaria, no continuó estudiando por razones económicas. Es madre soltera de un niño de nueve meses.
Su negocio consiste en la venta ambulante de ropa. Compra ropa en los puestos de ropa y sale a ofrecerla de puerta en puerta. Con su primer crédito de S/. 300 que canceló en 4 cuotas, compró ropa de adulto y de bebé.
Con este crédito de S/. 500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará ropa para Navidad.
Edith sueña con tener una tienda muy grande.
texts.en:
Edith Gisela is nineteen years old, the treasurer for the Manuel Seoane Support Group, and lives on Manuel Carera St. Mz 20 lot 2 of the district Esperanza, in the province of Trujillo, apartment La Libertad, Peru. She studied until freshman year of high school and did not continue for financial reasons. She is the single mother of a nine-month-old child. Her business is in traveling clothing sales. She buys cloths from clothing stalls and then she goes to sell them door-to-door. With her first loan of S/. 300, which she repaid in four installments, she bought baby cloths and cloths for adults. With this loan of S/. 500, which will be repaid in four installments, she will buy Christmas cloths. Edith dreams of having a very big store.

Translated from Spanish by Hannah Lily, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing Christmas cloths

loans.name: Jovita

texts.es:
La señora Jovita tiene 67 años D. edad, pertenece al Grupo Solidario Manuel Seoane y vive en la calle Alexander Pettion 1155 del distrito La Esperanza, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta tercer grado D. primaria, pero no siguió estudiando porque murió su madre. Se casó D. 15 años y tiene 7 hijos casados.
Su negocio consiste en la venta D. pollo. Ella lo despresa en su casa y lo venD. por pedidos y también en el Mercado La Hermelinda.
Con este crédito D. S/. 300, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará pollo y también piensa guardar para comprar pollo para la Navidad, ya que es una fiesta donD. se venD. mucha carne D. ave.
Jovita sueña con ser mayorista en la venta D. pollo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Jovita is 67 years old and belongs to the Solidario Manuel Seoane group; she lives on Alexander Pettion Street in La Esperanza in the city of Trujillo in La Libertad, Peru. She studied through 3rd graD. of elementary school but could not continue because her mother passed away. She married at the age of 15 and she has 7 married children. She works selling chicken. She cuts the chicken in pieces in her home and sells it in the Hermelinda Market. With this $100 loan which she will repay in 4 installments, she will buy chicken and save some to sell during Christmas since it is traditionally a festival where people eat a lot of poultry. Jovita dreams of being a chicken wholesaler.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chicken

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es: La Sra. Ana habita en un barrio de la capital de Managua que se llama Leonel  Rugama, tiene 66 años de edad, con dos hijos uno se graduó de ingeniero en química, y el otro es taxista, los dos la apoyan con sus gastos,  su esposo ya falleció, tiene un tramo de venta de ropa en un mercado que se llama Roberto Huembes, inicio con dinero que su hijo mayor le dio, las ventas han bajado desde que la canasta básica subió de precio, pero no de deja de vender, con este préstamo desea invertir en ropa variada para la temporada navideña ya que las ventas son buenas para esta época, a futuro es dejar establecido su negocio y ampliar su línea de crédito.
texts.en:
Ana lives in a neighbourhood of the capital Managua called Leonel Rugama. She is 66 years old and has two children: one graduated in chemical engineering and the other drives a taxi. Both her children help her with her expenses; her husband has passed away. She has a stall selling clothes in the Roberto Huembes market. She started her business with money her elder child gave her. Sales have dropped with the rising cost of basic foods. However, she continues to sell and plans to invest this loan in a variety of clothes for the holiday season as seasonal sales are good. In the future, she wants to further establish her business and increase her line of credit.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of children's and adult's clothing.

loans.name: Maritza Violeta

texts.es:
La señora Maritza Violeta tiene 23 de edad, es secretaria del Grupo Solidario Manuel Seoane y vive en la invasión Los Jardines del distrito La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta tercer año de secundaria y ya no continuó estudiando porque tuvo su bebé, pero piensa continuar ahora que su niño tiene mayor  edad.
Su negocio consiste en la venta de ropa por pedido.
Con este crédito de S/. 300, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará panetones para venderlos por Navidad.
Maritza desea tener un puesto de ropa o una tienda grande.
texts.en:
Ms. Maritza Violeta is 23 years old and lives in the Los Jardines region of the La Esperanza district, province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad, Perú. She is the secretary of the Manuel Seoane Solidarity Group.

She studied up to her third year of high school but was unable to continue with her education because she had a baby. However, she plans on resuming her studies now that her son is older.

Her business consists of selling clothing by catalog. With this loan of 300.00 PEN, which will be repaid in 4 monthly installments, she will purchase panetones (Peruvian holiday fruitcake) to sell them for Christmas. Maritza would like to have either her own clothing stand or a big store.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Peruvian holiday fruitcake

loans.name: Rosa Analy

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Analy tiene 23 años de edad, pertenece al Grupo Solidario Génesis y vive en la calle Juan Velasco Alvarado Mz. 3 lote 20 El Milagro, distrito de Huanchaco, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Terminó secundaria, pero no continuó estudiando porque se casó y tiene 2 hijas de 4 y 2 años respectivamente.
Su negocio consiste en la venta de jugo, ensalada de fruta, desayuno con pescado frito, etc. Se podría llamar una pequeña fuente de soda. El negocio funciona en su casa.
Con su primer crédito de S/. 300 que canceló en 4 cuotas, compró hielo, fruta y colorantes para raspadilla.
Con este crédito de S/. 600, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará yogur, fruta, pescado para los desayunos, golosinas.
Rosa sueña con estudiar Administración de Empresas y ser una gran empresaria de su propio negocio.
texts.en:
Rosa Analy is 23 years old. She finished high school but did not continue her education because she got married. She has two daughters, a 2 year old and a 4 year old. She is a member of the Grupo Solidario Génesis and live on Juan Velasco Alvarado Mz. Street, Lot 20 'El Milagro', in the district of Huanchaco, in the province of Trujillo, in the region of La Libertad, Perú. Rosa runs a business selling juice, fruit salad, breakfasts of fried fish etc. You could call it a little soda shop. She runs it out of her house. With her first loan of 300 soles, which she repaid in 4 installments, Rosa bought ice, fruit and food coloring for snow cones. With this next loan of 600 soles, which will also be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy yogurt, fruit, candy, and fish. Rosa's dream is to study Business Administration and to be in charge of her own successful business.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Sultan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy yogurt, fruit, candy and fish

loans.name: Dolly Esther

texts.es:
La señora Dolly Esther tiene 38 años de edad, es secretaria del Grupo Solidario Génesis y vive en la calle Las Praderas Mz. B lote 6 El Milagro, distrito de Huanchaco, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió Enfermería Técnica en el Instituto Libertad, pero no trabaja en su profesión debido a la falta de plazas de empleo. Se casó a los 19 años y tiene dos hijos varones de 18 y 15 años respectivamente.
Su negocio consiste en la venta de carne de cerdo, de res y de carnero. Su negocio se ubica en el Mercado Santa Rosa, puesto 148 de El Milagro. Con su primer crédito de S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas compró menudencia de res.
Con este crédito de S/. 500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará tres carneros en carne.
Dolly sueña con ser una vendedora mayorista.
texts.en:
Dolly Esther is 38 years old, and the secretary for the Genesis Solidarity Group. She lives on Las Praderas Street in El Milagro, Huanchaco district, in La Libertad, Perú. She studied nursing at the Libertad Institute, but she doesn’t practice her profession given the lack of jobs in that area. She married at nineteen and has two sons who are 18 and 15 years old respectively. Her business consists of the sale of pork, beef and mutton. The enterprise is located at the Santa Rosa Market, post 148, of El Milagro. With her first loan of 300.00 soles, canceled in four months, she purchased beef giblets. With this loan of 500.00 soles, to be repaid in four installments, she will buy three sheep. Dolly dreams of becoming a wholesaler.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase three sheep.

loans.name: Adelia Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora  Adelia del carmen C., tiene la edad de 34 años habita en el sector de buenos aires ubicado en el municipio de Ticuantepe, junto a su esposo y  hijos los cuales actualmente estudian y le ayudan cuando hay producción, el esposo de doña Adelina trabaja como jardinero en una casa privada para ayudarle con los gastos del hogar y le apoya en la agricultura a la vez. La señora se dedica a la agricultura y va a  vender al mercado oriental, ella comenzó su negocio de los mismo que cultiva, pero eso solo lo hacia cuando sale la cosecha; después de un tiempo decidió comprar frutas y verduras que con sus propios esfuerzos y de su esposo ha logrado establecer un poco su negocio. Con la ayuda de Afodenic que durante tres préstamos la ha apoyado, la señora se siente contenta porque su producción la vende a mejor precio, por los insumos que le aplica con cada préstamo que financia nuestra institución.
texts.en:
Adelia del Carmen C. is 34 years old and lives with her husband and children in the Ticuantepe municipality of Buenos Aires. Her children lend a hand when it's harvest time. Adelia's husband works as a gardener at another house to help out with the household expenses and also helps out in the crops. Adelia is a farmer and sells her produce at the oriental market. She started her business with the income she made from the sales of produce, but the income would only happen if the harvest did. So, she decided to buy fruits and vegetables to sell and with much effort, she and her husband have been able to establish their business. With the continued support of Afodenic, Adelia has been able to afford fertilizing her crops, and as such, has been able to sell her produce for a better price -- which makes her very happy.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and poison

loans.name: Elsa Ene

texts.es:
La señora Elsa tiene 36 años de edad, es tesorera de su Grupo Solidario Génesis y vive en la calle Juan Velasco Alvarado Mz 4 lote 19 El Milagro, distrito de Huanchaco, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió Farmacia Técnica, pero no trabaja en su carrera porque los sueldos no corresponden a la realidad. Tiene una hija de 6 años que depende enteramente de ella.
Elsa empezó a trabajar con una bodega, lugar donde vende toda clase de abarrotes. Con sus ganancias puso un video pub el cual le da mucha ganancia. Actualmente tiene también una cebichería, el negocio se desarrolla en su propia casa. Con su primer crédito de S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas, invirtió en la bodega.
Con este crédito de S/. 500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, instalará el sistema de agua para su negocio.
Elsa sueña con viajar y conocer el extranjero.
texts.en:
Elsa is 36 years old, and the treasurer for the Genesis Solidarity Group. She lives on Juan Velasco Alvarado Street in El Milagro, Huanchaco district, in La Libertad, Perú. She studied as a pharmacist, but doesn’t practice her profession because the salaries are not realistic. She has a small 6-year old daughter who wholly depends on her. Elsa started to work with a grocery store, where she sells all types of products. With her earnings, she initiated a video pub which generates good profits. Currently, she also has a cebichería (food sales) which she runs out of her own home. With her first loan of 300.00 soles, which was canceled in four months, she invested in the grocery store. With this loan of 500.00 soles, to be repaid in four installments, she will install a water system for her business. Elsa dreams of traveling and getting to know other places.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To install a water system for her business.

loans.name: Eufemia Magna

texts.es:
La señora Eufemia Magna tiene 40 años D. edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal Nueva Esperanza II y vive en la calle San Pablo 620 Interior A del sector Jerusalén, distrito La Esperanza, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta tercer año D. secundaria, no continuó estudiando porque se quedó huérfana D. ambos padres y su hermano se hizo cargo D. ella. Al casarse su hermano ya no pudo continuar apoyándola. Ella se casó a los 16 años y tiene 3 hijos, D. los cuales el mayor ya trabaja y los dos últimos todavía son estudiantes.
Magnita, como cariñosamente la llaman todos sus familiares y conocidos, venD. D. casa en casa utensilios y artefactos electrodomésticos. Viaja a la sierra liberteña o a otros departamentos a ofrecer sus productos. 
Agradece mucho al Movimiento Manuela Ramos porque gracias a sus créditos pudo obtener capital y trabajar como lo hace actualmente. Con el primer crédito D. S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas, empezó a trabajar y fue creciendo, porque compró muy poco pero lo supo invertir.
Con este crédito D. S/. 1,500, lo cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, comprará paraguas, radios, tapers, cubrecamas y otros.
Magnita desea tener una tienda granD. y poner una fábrica D. zapatos.
texts.en:
Eufemia Magna, 40, belongs to the Nueva Esperanza II ["New Hope II"] community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She left school in the third graD.. She wasn't able to continue her schooling because both her parent died, leaving her an orphan in the care of her brother. When he married, he wasn't able to go on supporting her. She married at 16 and has 3 children, the oldest of whom works. The younger two are still in school. Magnita, as she's lovingly known, sells household goods, door-to-door. She travels throughout La Libertad and other "departamentos" selling her goods. She's very grateful to Manuela Ramos because the money she's borrowed has allowed her to do what she does. With the first loan of S/.300 [300 Peruvian soles], repaid in 4 installments, she began her business, buying little but wisely. With this loan of S/.1,500, to be repaid in 6 installments, she will buy umbrellas, radios, tablecloths, bedspreads and other products. Magnita's dream is to have a large store and set up a shoe factory.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Sara Maria

texts.es:
La señora Sara María tiene 41 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal Nueva Esperanza II y vive en la calle San Pablo 657 sector Jerusalén, distrito La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió secundaria completa y además un año de curso de inyectables. Por falta de recursos ya no continuó estudiando. Se casó a los 23 años y actualmente tiene 5 hijos que dependen de ella dos estudiantes.
Su negocio consiste en la venta de bebida y prepara menú por pedido.
Con su primer crédito de S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas, compró cerveza y cosas para el menú.
Con este crédito de S/. 1,500, lo cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, invertirá en ropa para las fiestas navideñas, también invertirá en juguetes.
Sara sueña con ver a sus hijos profesionales.
texts.en:
Sara María is 41 years old, belongs to the communal bank Nueva Esperanza II, and lives on San Pablo Street in the La Esperanza district of La Libertad, Perú. She completed her secondary school studies, as well as one year of a course on injectables. Due to lack of resources, she did not continue her studies. She married at 23, and currently has five children who depend on her, two of whom are students. Her business consists of the sale of beverages, and she prepares food on order. With her first loan of 300.00 soles, canceled in four quotas, she purchased beer and ingredients for her menu. With this loan of 1,500.00 soles, to be repaid in six installments, she will invest in the purchase of clothing for the holiday season as well as in toys. Sara dreams of seeing her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in clothing and toys.

loans.name: Sophan

texts.en: Mrs. Sophan S. is a farmer in Phlaov Trey village in Kandal Province. She owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables to earn a living. On her plantation, she faces a problem because her field is far from an irrigation system, which is bad for her crops. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a pump to support and water her field. She hopes to make her crop more productive with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Koeut Tith, drives a motorbike taxi. Mrs. Sophan S. is 38 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in garment factory, while another three are attending the local school, and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown with her on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a pump to water her rice and vegetable field.

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en: Mrs. Yeng T. is a 55-year-old widow, and she now lives in Moat Boeng village in Kandal Province. She is a farmer and owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. On the plantation she gathers little rice revenue to support her family. In order to improve her living, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions after she sells the cow. Mrs. Yeng T. has two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the other is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy a cow to start a breeding business.

loans.name: Sorphea

texts.en: Mrs. Sorphea S. is a farmer in Trapaing Suom village in Takeo Province. She owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Or Da, is a construction worker. Even though they have different businesses, they earn little income to provide a better life for their family. Thus, Mrs. Sorphea S. decided to ask for a loan to combine with her saving to buy timber to build a house for her family. She is 35 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, while the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To add her saving to buy timber to build a house for her family.

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhom A. is a farmer, and she lives in Trapaing Suom village in Takeo province. She owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. She now faces an obstacle in that she usually pays a lot of money to have her field plowed. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy an ox to help her old ox plow the field, to reduce her family's expense. Her husband, Mr. Ya Seiv An, is a construction worker. Mrs. Sokhom A. is 41 years old and the mother of six children -- one of whom is a farmer, while another four are enrolled in the local school, and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is also presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy an ox to help her old one plow the field to reduce her family's expense.

loans.name: Chek

texts.en: Mr. Chek M. is a villager in Neil village in Takeo Province. He is an ice cream seller in the local village. Because his business is going well, he wants to expand it; thus, he decided to ask for a loan to combine with his savings to buy a motorbike to transport his ice cream and sell door-to-door. He hopes to increase his income and provide a better life for his family. His wife, Mrs. Eam Vy, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mr. Chek M. is 26 years old and the father of two children who are too young to work or study because they are one and four years old. His wife is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To combine with his savings and buy a motorbike to transport his ice cream and sell door-to-door.

loans.name: Set

texts.en: Mrs. Set B. is a 45-year-old and lives in Angk village in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Muong Samai, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. On this plantation, they face some problems because they do not have enough rice seed to cultivate. Therefore, Mrs. Set B. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seeds to cultivate, and she would use the rest of the money to purchase fertilizers and fuel to make her crop more productive. Mrs. Set B. has five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizers, and fuel to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: San

texts.en: Mrs. San P. is a 44-year-old widow and lives in Angk village in Kandal Province. She is a farmer who has a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. She now faces some problems because her field is far from an irrigation system.  Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a water pump, rice seed, and fertilizer, and the rest of money to hire laborers to work in the field. She hopes to increase her rice revenue with this loan. Mrs. San P. has four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, while another is a farmer to help the mother, and the other is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy a pump, rice seed, and fertilizer, and to hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en: Mrs. Sareth S. is a 44-year-old widow, and she lives in So Sean village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a vegetable seller in the local market. Because her business is going well, she wants to expand it; thus, Mrs. Sareth S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase more vegetables for her sales. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living with this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lailani

texts.en:
Leilanie G., 36 years old, is married and is blessed with three children. She lives in the peaceful village of Compania Tumauini, Isabela, near the public market of Tumauini, Philippines. 

Leilanie sells fish. She and her husband wake up very early in the morning every day to go to the market and sell fresh fish. She is grateful that she can earn at least Php5, 000.00 each week from her fish business.  She carefully budgets her income, which includes food, the school allowances of their children, and rolling capital for her business.  

Her husband travels to Manila to buy large volume of fish at wholesale prices that they will sell in their town at retail prices.  Thus, in order for them to purchase huge volumes of fish, Leilanie is requesting a loan of Php5, 000.00 to sustain and grow their business, which will increase their income.  

She and her husband are working hard to provide a better life for their children.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Sokkhoeun

texts.en: Mr. Sokkhoeun S. is a villager in Svay Rak village in Kampong Cham Province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He can gather little income to support his family with his current plantation. In order to improve his living, he decided to ask for a loan to buy a piece of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. S. Sokkaiy, is a pig breeder. Mr. Sokkhoeun S. is 29 years old and the father of two children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study. His wife is also presented with him in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land to cultivate rice

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Mrs. Ny N. lives in Svay Prey village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a pig breeder. Because her business is going well, she wants to expand it; thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for her pig breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and provide a better life for her family's living conditions. Her husband, Mr. Sum Sophat, is a farmer who cultivates rice. Mrs. Ny N. is 23 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is two years old. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for her pig breeding business.

loans.name: Khoeurn

texts.en: Mr. Khoeurn K. is a farmer in Tang Chrey village in Kampong Cham Province. He owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. His wife, Mrs. Sout Korn, is a duck breeder. Because her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, Mr. Khoeurn K. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducklings and duck food for the duck breeding business. By expanding the poultry business, he hopes to earn additional income and to provide a better life for his children. He is 45 years old and the father of six children, three of whom are workers in different positions, while another two are enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. His wife is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more ducklings and duck food for the duck breeding business.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
After eight years of settling in Ballacong, Lilibeth observed that their village is continually developing in terms of livelihood, road condition, and education, but many poor families are still striving to fight poverty. 

Their village is an agricultural area where different vegetables, roots crops, corn, rice, watermelon etc. are planted. Lilibeth’s husband is a government employee with a modest monthly income. In order to help him provide for their family’s needs and for the education of their two children, Lilibeth opened a business selling and e-loading (adding prepaid minutes) mobile phones.

The growing demands for e-loading motivated her to go into this type of business. Lilibeth enjoys the business, because selling loads to distant areas helps to connect people all over the world. However, due to the increasing demands on mobile phone loads, she does not have enough capital to purchase the thousands of load wallets she needs to satisfy her daily customers.

She is asking for a loan of Php5, 000 which will be sufficient for her to be able to expand her business.

“Though their life is very tough, they do not lose hope and continue to dream on,” Lilibeth shares. She and her husbandwill work hand in hand to make their two children become good people who have good attitudes and are disciplined. Their ultimate dream is to be able to send their children  to college to have a brighter future.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Morbb

texts.en: Mrs. Morbb Y. is 48 years old, and she lives in Krodas Khor village in Kampong Cham Province. She and her husband, Mr. Phoung Hour, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn their living. On this plantation, they face a small problem because their field is infertile, which affects their crop. In order to deal this problem, Mrs. Morbb Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to enable her field to make her crop more productive. She has three children -- one of whom is a palm juice collector, while another is a laborer who has been hired by a villager to plow a field, and the other is attending the local school. Her husband is presented in the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support her field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel is married and is blessed with 2 small children. She lives in a simple house located in the rural place of Barangay Ballacong Ilagan, in Isabela, Philippines. Ballacong is located in the midst of corn fields and is considered to be an upland place in Ilagan. Agriculture is the primary source of income. Maribel has to bear with the poor road conditions just to bring their harvested rice grains to the market. 
	
Maribel sells rice to earn income and support her family’s needs. She is glad that she is able to respond to the “rice needs” of her neighbors. Maribel has been in the rice retailing business for three years.  She believes that this business will become more successful than the other businesses in the area because rice is the most important staple food in the country. She has always encountered shortages in her stocks because of its very high demand.
	
She is asking for a loan of P5,000 to buy more rice and to avoid her previous experiences. She believes that this money will really help her business. She knows that all her dreams will come true if she can earn more income. She also doubles her time and sacrifices a lot in order to reach all her dreams which include sending her children to school and having her house repaired.

Faith in God and the good relationship among her family serve as her inspiration.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Phat

texts.en: Mrs. Phat P. is a villager in Pour village in Kampong Cham Province. She and her husband, Mr. Choem Choeun, are farmers who have a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. They face some problems because their field's soil is infertile, and they generally pay a lot of money to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow their field. In order to deal with these problems, Mrs. Phat P. decided to ask for a loan to buy an ox and fertilizer to support her field. She is 58 years old and the mother of four children -- one of whom is employed in garment factory, while the others are construction workers. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy an ox and fertilizer to support her field.

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en: Mrs. Pheap K. is 33 years old and lives in Pour village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a tailor. Aside from this business, she is a pig breeder. Because her pig breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more piglets, pig food, and medicine for her pig breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living after she sells her pigs. Her husband, Mr. Chi Mengly, is a farmer.  Mrs. Pheap K. has two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, pig food, and medicine for her pig breeding business.

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en: Mr. Khiev N., 30, is a rice farmer who lives in the Batchenhchean commune in Pursat Province. His wife, Mrs. Touch Sokhom, 25, is a local farmer.  She is a mother of two children, who are both still too young to attend primary school. They have both been farmers since 1990 and have much experience in this occupation.  They are widely known as skilled rice cultivators. Khiev requests a $400 loan to buy a buffalo to help plow his field.

loans.use: to buy a buffalo

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhom C. is a villager in the Ar Rak village in Kampong Cham Province. Mrs. Sokhom C. is 27 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. She is a full-time pig breeder. Since her pigs are growing bigger and bigger, she does not have enough money to continue to breed them. Thus, she has decided to request a loan to purchase some pig food for her business. 

Her husband, Mr. Sanh Vai, is a motorbike taxi driver who makes less income in order to support the household. Her husband is pictured here next to her.

loans.use: To purchase some pig food for her pig breeding business.

loans.name: Meth

texts.en:
Mr. Meth M. is a farmer and lives in the Svay Prey village in Kampong Cham Province. He owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice in order to earn a living. His wife, Mrs. Chen Neam, is a pig breeder. 

Since her business is going well, she wishes to expand it; thus, Mr. Meth M. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food for her business. He hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. 

Mr. M. is 49 years old and the father of seven children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while two others stay at home to do housework and help the parents with chores. The remaining three are enrolled in the local school. His wife is shown with him here in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig food for his wife's business.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel’s family lives in Malamag West. She is married to Benito, a farmer, and is blessed with three children who motivate them to work hard. Their backyard is planted with vegetables, which gives her an average daily income of P150. She does not have to go to the market to purchase vegetables because she has ready supplies in her backyard.
	
She is always seen walking in her neighborhood with her basket filled with different varieties of vegetable.  She dreams of having her own tribike (a small bicycle with a carriage or sidecar) to be used as a rolling store. This will lessen her burden of carrying the vegetables she sells. She will use her loan of P3,000 to increase her capital and to buy the tribike.
 
Her ultimate goals in life are to live simply and provide for her children’s education.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn thought of opening a community-based variety store because the people in her village still go to the town to buy their basic items and other commodities.  

Her store is open from six o’clock in the morning until eight o’clock in the evening. She usually goes to the town’s public market twice a week to purchase commodities, but Marilyn wants to cut her transportation cost and maximize her time, especially when the road conditions are rough. She wants to go to the public market only once a week and buy in bulk, but she does not have enough capital to do this. 

She expects that a loan of P5,000 will give her more income. As such, she will be able to grow her business and help her husband, who is engaged in farming.  With their combined income, it is possible for them to reach their dreams of sending her children to school and be elevated from poverty.  

Marilyn shared her three priorities in life: to have good health, good family relationships, and faithfulness to God all the time.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Huon

texts.en: Mrs. Huon S., a widow, is 49 years old.  She makes a living by growing rice and vegetables including cabbage  and morning glory. She makes an income of around $2 per day, which is used to pay for her family's expenses. She has three children, all of which are employed. Her eldest is a carpenter, the second-eldest is a tailor, and the youngest helps her with her business. They all live in Pursat Province. Huon is requesting a $500 loan to buy a cow to help her plow her land.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn married at an early age of 18, but she did not take this as a reason to be discouraged and to regret the life she has now. Her husband, Orlan, is a former vegetable vendor, but is now plants eggplants in their backyard, where Marilyn gets most of her vegetables. They are blessed with three children and they need to be more patient and industrious to support their family’s growing needs. They live in the village of Malamag West, where people are hardworking and well-discipline. Planting native and yellow corn and different vegetables are the major sources of income in the area.

Marilyn sells different kinds of vegetables in their village, and she walks from house to house selling the harvested vegetables to her regular customers. The nature of her business taught Marilyn to be confident in dealing with other people. She uses her daily net income of Php100 to meet their immediate needs. It is a good thing that Marilyn knows how to budget well, because otherwise, her daily income would not be enough for their food, the children’s allowances, and other needs. 

Marilyn is now contemplating about expanding her business. She is asking for a loan of Php3, 000 to be able to  buy more vegetables, meat, eggs and dried fish.

According to Marilyn, she wants to help her husband to provide for their needs and to send their children to school.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
Mylene is a 29-year-old mom of two kids and a wife to Junrie, who is an electrician. She has a happy family bonded with trust and unity. She is striving to have a successful business to meet her family’s daily needs and provide for the future of her children. They live in the rural area of Barangay Antagan 2nd Tumauini, Isabela, Philippines, near the mountainside of Sierra Madre. She is so thankful that her neighbors are very hospitable, friendly and united. 

Mylene has  a small, community-based store. She sells various basic commodities like spices, soaps and shampoos, canned goods, coffee, and sugar. She also wants to sell other products that she thinks are needed in her community. In order to fulfill this, she must have additional money. She is currently earning a weekly income of P3,000 but she thinks this is not enough to buy the products that she wants to include in her store.  Fortunately, she is able to apply for a loan of Php 5,000 to a local institution that provides loans to small entrepreneurs like her.
 
 “ I have to be industrious in order to achieve my goal in life,” Mylene added.

Moreover, she will make sure that her loan will be wisely used, so that her business to be able to grow and ultimately become sustainable.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Yon

texts.en: Mrs. Yon N. is a 52-year-old widow. She makes a living running a small grocery store in front of her house in Pursat Province. She has four children, three of whom are married and employed, and one single daughter. Her daughter, Ms. Yon Phary, is 20 years old and raises pigs. N. is requesting a loan of 600,000 Riel ($150) to purchase more groceries to sell so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa, who is married and with two children, lives in Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabel, Philippines. She has a hog-raising business while her husband works on their farm. Currently, she has more than three pigs, but she is planning to raise additional piglets in order to improve her income. 

Since her husband has a limited income from his harvest, their earnings are not enough to buy additional piglets.  They will have to buy item to meet their family's needs and to buy food of her pigs first. So she needs a loan of Php7,000 from an institution which has been helping people like her who want to help themselves. Half of this amount will be used to buy additional piglets and pig food and to add pig pens.  
 
According to her, she does these things for the sake of her children’s education and their brighter future. She strongly believes that faith, religiosity, and strong bonding are the secrets of a successful family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi: Chị Ngọc năm nay 46 tuổi, Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1996. Trong những năm đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư cho chăn nuôi. Hiện nay công việc đem lại thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị là kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá.. Với mức thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng  kinh tế gia đình chị Ngọc rất ổn định  và thuận tiện cho việc hoàn trả vốn theo quy định. Vòng vố tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. Bui is 46 years old. She joined the Fund in 1996. In the first few years she borrowed money to invest in raising livestock. Currently the family's main source of income is a general store. With an income of 4,000,000 VND/month, the family's finances are very stable and well-suited for making the repayments in accordance with the terms and conditions. In this round of funding she would like to borrow 15,000,000 VND to invest in the family's store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her store

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Marilyn T., 53 years old, is a widow who lives in Upper Dicayas, Dipolog City. She has 6 children. Her husband died in 1999 and she has been the bread winner of the family since then. After the death of her husband, she found ways to earn a living. She sold their pig and started her barbeque with only 1,000 initial capital. 

She decided to join Paglaum MPC in November 2006 to get a loan for additional capital. Now she is borrowing PHP 14,000 to buy additional pork meat and sacks of farm fertilizer. 

She also owns a little parcel of land for farming. With her land, she was able to send her children to school, and two of them have already finished college. 

Mrs. T. plans to own a “carenderia” (small / mini restaurant) whose main menu is barbeque. She also wants to repair her house in the future.

loans.use: To buy additional pork meat and sacks of farm fertilizer

loans.name: Melchora

texts.en:
Mrs. Melchora Y., 60 years old, is married and lives in San Vicente, Dapitan City, Zamboanga Del Norte. She has 6 children, two of whom are in school, one in college and the other in high school.  Their only source of income is her "sari-sari" (variety) store.  She started her sari-sari store by selling only “puto,” a native Filipino snack made of ground rice, and bananas.  

Mrs. Melchora joined Paglaum MPC on September 28, 2007 to get a loan to finance her sari-sari store. Recently, she borrowed PHP 10,000 to purchase hundreds of rubber slippers to sell.  Mrs. Melchora was able to manage it well, with the help of her husband, and was able also to acquire a Video 5 Machine  (a videoke machine that she rents for P5 for 2 songs) with a combination of cash and credit. Paglaum helped them, especially with their financing, savings, and insurance.

In the future, Mrs. Y. dreams about having a mini-hardware store. She also wants to see her children finish their schooling and have a stable career someday.

loans.use: To purchase rubber slippers to sell

location.town: San Vicente, Dapitan City,Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Naseem M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Naseem baji is a 33-year-old woman who lives in Shah Rukn, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 22 years. Her husband, M. R., has a busiiness selling animals. He has been in this business for the past 10 years. She is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. 

Naseem baji works in a cotton factory where she packs cotton in sacks and earns $2 each day. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a loan to buy a buffalo to resell for a profit. 

She is the leader of a 5-person loan group. Zareena baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) for her animal business. Sumera baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk business. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy tools, mirrors, and chairs for her barber saloon. Fatima Mai baji wants a loan to buy an ox cart to fertilize her land. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: 'Baji,' which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo to sell

loans.name: Katerina

texts.en:
Katerina is married and has two grown children. She sells men's and women's underwear, t-shirts, and slippers at the central food market in Ivano-Frankivsk. Her monthly gross income is 6000 UAH.

Katerina has been in this business for 6 years. She used to work in construction; then as a janitor. The salary was small, so she decided to start working on her own. Katerina is a hard-working and determined person. At the moment, she has two kiosks. This business is the only source of income for her family.

Katerina would like to get 2500 UAH to purchase 200 men's slippers. This will enable her to significantly enlarge the variety of her inventory and make additional profit. She hopes to have enough goods to open a third kiosk at the same market. This will enable her to get more income amd improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase 200 men's slippers for sale

loans.name: Tausi Group

texts.en:
Meshack Rameck, age 34, is married with one son of 11 years. He has a chicken business which he started in 2003. He works daily from 8am until 6pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $238.

This will be Meshack’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the first loan to increase on the stock of his chicken and has paid the loan back successfully. He now hopes for a new loan to expand his chicken business.

Meshack will share this loan with subgroup A of the Tausi group. The subgroup has seven members, who run shops and sell charcoal and food. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Meshack is second from left, standing

loans.use: To buy more chickens for sale.

loans.name: Faizan Mai Manzoor Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Faizan Mai baji is a 43-year-old woman who lives in Shah Rukn, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house where she has been living for the past 10 years. She is the mother of one son who is 19 years old and works in an oil mill, where he packs cooking oil in cans. Faizan baji’s husband,M. A., is an animal seller with 20 years of experience in his business. 

Faizan baji  has a milk business. She has a buffalo at her home and she gets milk from her by getting up early in the morning. She sells the milk in the milk shops and charges 36 Pakistani Rupees for each kilogram of milk. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand her milk business. 

She is a the leader of a five-person loan group. Noreen Mai baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo and sell the milk.  Bashiran baji and Sakina Mai baji each want a loan to buy fertilizer to resell. Naseem Mai baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo for her milk business

loans.name: Gulum

texts.en:
Gulum S. is a 64-year-old woman who, assisted by her husband and two sons, breeds calves for meat production. Gulum has much experience in this field, her father having been a farmer who taught her a great deal about the business of cattle-raising.

The selling of cattle is her family’s only source of revenue. Gulum would now like to increase her income and so is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy four calves. Gulum and her family are counting on your help.

loans.use: To purchase four calves.

loans.name: Heyvagul

texts.en:
Heyvagul Q., 41, began raising cattle in southern Azerbaijan in 1994 when her husband lost his job, leaving her family without any means of subsistence. Taking the situation in hand, she borrowed money from friends to purchase two calves, and in less than six months was earning a stable income. Now Heyvagul is doing well and her four children are always nourished since she also keeps a cow for milk and yogurt production.

Heyvagul is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase four calves. Let’s do our best to help this brave woman.

loans.use: To purchase four calves.

loans.name: Taj Mai Haq Nawaz Group

texts.en:
Taj Mai baji is a 38-year-old lady and resides in a city named Shah Rukn, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 10 years. She is the mother of eight children: four sons and four daughters. Her eldest son is a ticket checker. The others are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.

Taj mai baji’s husband's name is H. N.; he is a driver and drives a truck for farming. Taj baji runs a shop where she sells seasonal vegetables. She has been running this shop for the past 15 years. Taj baji is applying for a loan to buy new wheels for her husband’s truck so that he able to continue his work.

She is the group leader and is joined by several more members from her locality. Farzana baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling. Mansab mai baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Nasreen mai baji and Bashiran mai baji each want a loan to buy fertilizer to re-sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy new wheels for her husband's truck

loans.name: Sien's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan for four borrowers. Mrs. Sien P., 30, is the group leader. She makes a living raising pigs as well as growing vegetables such as cabbage, morning glory, and water lilies to sell. She has two children, both of whom are still young and attend school. Her husband, Mr. Mao Sitha, 37, is a motorcycle taxi driver. Sien is applying for a $50 loan to purchase more piglets to raise.

The other three members of the group are: Mrs. Dong P., 50, is a Khmer wine distiller. She seeks a loan of $50 to buy a cart. Mrs. Sam C., 25, is a local construction worker who needs a loan of $50 to buy a piglet to raise. Mrs. Moeut P., 25, raises pigs for a living. She is requesting a $50 loan to purchase zinc to decorate her house.

The borrowers live in the Leangdaiy Commune in Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: to purchase more piglets to raise

loans.name: Elsavar

texts.en:
Elsavar I., a 30-year-old trader who is married and has two sons, started his business in 2006 and has already become a successful entrepreneur. Operating his store in an Internally Displaced People Settlement, he has gained much respect from the many people he respectfully serves every day. Elsavar sells a variety of goods including diapers, tooth paste, napkins, light bulbs, and macaroni. As well, he works at night as a security guard at the local factory, earning about $90 per month, an amount insufficient to meet basic family expenses.

Because the goods he sells are in high demand, he is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase additional inventory. Elsavar and his family thank everyone for their help.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Alverdi

texts.en:
Alverdi F., a 50-year-old farmer who lives in a small village in southern Azerbaijan, began raising calves for meat production in 1988 after losing his job. He currently has three calves which he will sell in the spring and a milking cow which provides milk for his wife and four children.

Because it is difficult to meet all of the needs of such a large family, he is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase four more calves in order to ultimately earn a larger profit. Your generosity can help improve the lives of Alverdi and his family.

loans.use: To purchase four calves.

loans.name: Razia Mai M.azam Group

texts.en:
Razia Mai baji is a 52-year-old lady and resides in a city named Shah Rukn, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 50 years. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. All of her sons are involved in a food-selling business. Both of her daughters stay at home and do household work.

Razia baji’s husband is a mason by profession with an experience of 30 years. Razia baji herself has a decorative embroidery business. She does embroidery on scarves and sells them in cloth markets, earning US$ 3 per scarf. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy mason's tools for her husband.

She is the group leader of several more members from her locality. Khamir baji wants a loan to buy seeds to re-sell. Ameeran baji wants a loan to buy tools for agriculture. Allah Jeevai baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Kaneeza baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for delivering loads.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy masonry tools

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is divorced and has two grown-up children. She sells vegetables and fruits at the central food market. Her business is quite successful because of its good location and reasonable prices. Her monthly net income is 2000 UAH.

Galina has been in this business for 5 years. The company she used to work for downsized and she was left without any income. She decided to open the food business. For a while it was the only source of income for her family.  

Galina would like to get a loan in the amount of 3000 UAH to purchase 100 lbs. of oranges, 50 lbs. of cucumbers, and 50 lbs. of tomatoes and other vegetables. She hopes that increased variety will bring more customers. Galina uses her income to help provide for her children and grandchildren.

loans.use: to purchase 100 lbs. of oranges, 50 lbs. of cucumbers, and 50 lbs. of tomatoes and other vegetables

loans.name: Sam Oeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Oeurn T. is a villager in the Pour Dos Village in Takeo Province. She is 28 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the remaining two are too young to work or study. 

She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land that she uses to cultivate rice to earn a living. On this plantation, she usually collects rice revenue every January. Her husband, Mr. Bes Pumngear, is a window designer who makes an income of around $5 each day - which is only a small percentage needed for the household expenses. 

Although Mrs. Sam Oeurn T. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot improve their poor life style. In order to improve it, Mrs. Sam Oeurn T. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to start her very own cow breeding business. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase a cow to in order to start a cow breeding business to increase their household income.

loans.name: Tausi E Group

texts.en:
Siwa S., age 40, is married with four children ages 14, 12, 10 and 8. She sells plastic shoes and some plates and bowls. She started her business six months ago and works daily from 8am until 6pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of about $40. Siwa hopes for a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase on the stock of her shoes.

Siwa will share this loan with subgroup E of the Tausi group. The subgroup has six members who run shops, have salons, and sell clothes and soft drinks. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Siwa is first on the left, standing

loans.use: To increase on her stock of plastic shoes.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Mrs. Sao E. was born in 1972 and now lives in the Smorn Pream Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Sao E. has a child who is six years old, who is now attending the local school. 

Mrs. E. has a small piece of land where she cultivates rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. HE. Ho, is a motorbike taxi driver. Since both these business activities generate a small income and their family members live in an old house, Mrs. Sao E. has decided to ask for a loan. She hopes to add to her savings so that she can build a new house for her household. Hopefully this will improve their living conditions. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To build a new house for her family so that their living conditions and quality of life is improved.

loans.name: Noem

texts.en:
Mrs. Noem Y. lives in the Ta Prass Village in Takeo Province. She owns a small piece of land that she uses to cultivate rice in order to earn a living. Aside from this plantation, she is a poultry breeder who raises ducks. Since this business is going well, she wishes to expand it. Thus, she has decided to request a loan so that she can buy more ducklings for breeding; she would use the rest of the loan to purchase duck food for her ducks. 

Her husband, Mr. Nak Vuthea, is a house constructor who makes a small income to support the household. Mrs. Noem Y. is 37 years old and the mother of three children, who are all attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more ducklings to breed and to purchase duck food for her ducks.

loans.name: Kroeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Kroeurn U. is a villager in the Ta Prass Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Kroeurn U. is 51 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are employed in different businesses, while the youngest one is attending the local school. 

She is a farmer who usually gathers a small percentage of rice revenue to support the household. Her husband, Mr. Keo Touch, is a duck breeder. Since his duck business is doing well, he wishes to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Kroeurn U. has decided to ask for a loan in order to buy more ducklings for her husband's breeding business. Additionally, she would use the rest of the loan to buy duck food for her current business. Her husband is shown with her in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more ducklings for her husband's breeding business.

loans.name: Kimly

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimly N. was born in 1979 and she now lives in the Kor Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land that she uses to cultivate rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile. This affects her crops very negatively. 

In order to deal with this problem, she has decided to ask for a loan that she can use to buy fertilizers to make her crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. Khat Ret, is a laborer who makes a small income to support the household. Mrs. Kimly N. has three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study as she is only one year old. Her husband is also pictured here with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer in order to replant her crops and make them healthier.

loans.name: Ileje Group

texts.en:
Hosea N., age 26, is single. He has a butcher shop which he started three years ago. He opens his butcher shop from 7am to 6pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $122.

In the past Hosea has taken out one loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy a refrigerator and to paint the shop. He hopes for a new loan to start selling fish in the same shop.

Hosea will share this loan with his loan group, Ileje, which totals 16 members. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture Hosea is in the middle of the front row.

loans.use: To start selling fish in addition to meat in his butcher's shop.

loans.name: Ari Mpya Group

texts.en:
Rehema Hassan, age 47, is married with four children ages 22, 20, 18 and 15. She also takes care of her mother. She has a fish business which she started four years ago and works daily from 6am until 2pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $375.

This will be Rehema’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the stock of fish and she repaid the loans successfully. She now hopes for the fourth loan to buy more stock of fish as she is now having more orders and she is going to pay her child’s school fees as well.

Rehema will share this loan with her loan group, Ari Mpya, which totals 17 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Rehema is to the left of the person in red in the front row.

loans.use: To buy more fish and pay children's school fees.

loans.name: Hun

texts.en: Hun K., 28, is single and resides with her mother and grandmother in Prey Veng, Cambodia. Since 2007, she has been worked selling beef to earn a living and is able to make US$ 4 in profit a day. She would like to purchase a motorbike to transport stuff from home to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to use for her business

loans.name: Mrs. Sophat Brang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank consists of twelve members and is located in the Tuol Tbaeng village in Takeo Province. They plan to use the loan which they have obtained for different purposes. 

Mrs. Sophat B. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members.  She is 32 years old and the mother of four children who are attending the local school. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land that shes uses to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Chea Thoeun, is a teacher in the local school and makes a small salary of which cannot improve his household's living conditions by much. 

Even though they have different business activities, they still earn too little income to support their family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sophat B. has decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets to start a pig breeding business. She hopes to increase their combined income and provide a better life for her children.

Two members in this village bank loan possess end-of-term loans and the rest of have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy piglets to start a pig breeding business.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch V., 32, is married and resides with her husband and two young children in the Prey Veng, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has been selling various kinds of vegetables to earn a living and is able to make US$ 2 in profit a day, while her husband, 34, is a motor-taxi driver. Every day, he operates around the market near his house and generally produces US$ 2 in profit as well. Two of their children are students. 

Touch V. would like to take out a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to run his motor-taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband's business

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn S., 32, is married and lives with her husband and five of her children in Prey Veng, Cambodia. She and her husband are farm workers. They normally hire an individual grower to plow their farmland. On average, this couple earns a combined US$ 2 a day. All of their children are students.

Sorn S. would like to request a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a grinding mill to service the people in the village for additional profit to help support their family. (Sorn S. is pictured with her husband and two children.)

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill to use to earn extra revenue

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work.

loans.name: Razia M. Nawaz Group

texts.en:
Razia baji is a 50 year old woman that resides in Shah Rukn, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 40 years. She is the mother of four children: three daughters and one son.
